title: What will happen to the European Union's sectoral sanctions against Russia, currently set to expire in July 2016?
possible_answers: Some of the sanctions will be extended, but others will be relaxed or allowed to expire

http://www.rferl.org/content/eu-extends-russia-sanctions/27832650.html
RUSSELS -- The European Union has officially decided to extend its economic sanctions against Russia to January 31, 2017.  The decision to roll over the measures was made by EU ambassadors already last week, but Italy slowed down the confirmation process and insisted that the final decision be taken after the EU summit in Brussels on June 28-29.  The decision was finally taken by a so-called written procedure in which all the EU member states capitals had to approve the prolongation within a specific time frame that ended on July 1. The decision will now be published in the EU official journal on July 2. The sanctions, which hits Russia's energy and banking sector and also target specific Russian politicians, were first adopted by Brussels in June and July 2014 after Russia's forcible annexation of Crimea and its intervention in eastern Ukraine.

(+) up on extending and (-) on some/but others; I think there is real likelihood they discuss a 'gradual' lifting of the sectoral sanctions, a small chance the come up with a plan to do so, but very little chance its implemented before 31 July. http://www.econotimes.com/EU-may-go-for-conditional-sanctions-against-Russia-in-next-weeks-extension-223877 "European Union members are due this week to take decisions on sanctions against Russia imposed over the former’s conflict with Ukraine, whether to extend or not and most likely outcome is a conditional and gradual one. Austrian minister of foreign affairs, Sebastian Kurz said yesterday that it is time for the European Union to find common ground with Russia. He said, “I believe that we should gradually come to a modus in which for every implementation of the Minsk Protocol, for every single step, sanctions will gradually be lifted in return”. His views echoed the comments made by German foreign minister, Frank Walther stein Meier, who said that the European Union should consider phasing out the sanctions gradually with progress. These views are in sharp contrast to German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s view that sanctions should only be lifted when compliance with Minsk agreement is at full. However, hardliners are being forced to reconsider their positions in Ukraine crisis as they will need Russian cooperation in bigger conflicts in Syria, which has triggered European refugee crisis. EU members are most likely to extend the sanctions at the meeting, however, it will suggest on the guidelines for reducing the sanctions."

The sectoral sanctions pertain to four areas:
1. Limit access to EU primary and secondary capital markets for 5 major Russian majority state-owned financial institutions and their majority-owned subsidiaries established outside of the EU, as well as three major Russian energy and three defence companies
2. Impose an export and import ban on trade in arms
3. Establish an export ban for dual-use goods for military use or military end users in Russia
4. Curtail Russian access to certain sensitive technologies and services  that can be used for oil production and exploration
---------------
Probability of easing sanctions on 2 & 3 is negligible, but what about 1 & 4? It is unlikely, as EU will want to set the right tone prior to the next US administration coming in, but can't discount it altogether either.  Going in at 85%.

Given the lack of discussion on the issue, or any progress on the Ukraine conflict (in fact, it's recently gotten worse) and the short time frame, it's almost certain that the sanctions will be extended.

As long as Russia continues its belligerent stance under the current leadership, I believe that the sanctions will be extended. Most optimistically, I only see a partial expiry of some sanctions. There will not be a full expiry of all sanctions. I believe an important consideration in determining whether the sanctions will expire or be extended is the Russian occupation of the Ukrainian territory of Crimea (which some will claim is illegal under international law). As things currently stand, it seems highly unlikely that Russia will return Crimea to Ukraine peacefully, especially as the Russian navy still houses its Black Sea fleet there. Furthermore, the world's focus on Crimea's occupation has waned over the years, and global attention is currently focused on other ongoing crises and geopolitical events (e.g. the Zika virus, Islamic State, US 2016 Presidential election). This puts less pressure on Russia to move its military away from Crimea.
Ukraine is to Russia what Russia is to the EU, as long as Ukraine is ineffective to Russia, then Russia is OK with it. As long as Russia is ineffective against Europe, the EU is ok with it.

These include issue fatigue, energy or other economic concerns, and the pressure of nations friendlier to Moscow, such as Hungary.

"The critical 2016 Warsaw summit, to be held July 8-9 among NATO members, is fast approaching. Out of the summit, the United States hopes a clear, united purpose will emerge for the divided security alliance. The key challenge for Washington will be to reassure its Eastern European allies, especially Poland and the Baltic states, that they will be supported against Russia, an ever-increasing concern now that Moscow has invested itself militarily in Ukraine. The United States has already taken measures to bolster forces on NATO's eastern flank, but these forces are currently little more than a symbol of U.S. commitment" and
"These fears are driving protests in Russia as well as Moscow's defense spending. Despite its considerable nuclear arsenal, Russia continues to prioritize its strategic missile force. Last year, the Russians tested eight intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs), and in January, Russian officials announced plans to test 16 ICBMs in 2016, 14 of which will be entering service in Russia. On the testing schedule are the recently introduced Bulava submarine-launched ballistic missiles, which had considerable development problems, and other land-based ICBMs, such as the new SS-X-30 Sarmat. Moscow is counting on these missiles as well as new deployment tactics to ensure its nuclear arsenal can survive the U.S. anti-ballistic missile network"

According to the EU the sanctions can only expire in full or in part if there is full implementation of the Minsk agreement. This reading would seem not to allow of the partial relaxation of sanctions- it will be all or none. I'm supposing that in practice though the EU would like to have a little wiggle room to either 1) encourage a more conciliatory Russian response, or 2) maintain unanimous support for some sanctions amongst all the  EU members of which at least 5 of the 28 are said to be wavering. With limited time remaining, lifting of sanctions is a long shot.

One side: OSCE police mission will make clear vision in that region, market expansion in Russia for European agrarians, increasing the numbers of supporters (lifting of sanctions), necessity of resolution in July (encouragement of Russia actions in that conflict) Another side: negative perception of Russia, harsh performances of Ukrainian Nationalists, military actions on both sides, conflict can be classified as long-term problem

The mood in European politics is to do nothing and focus on keeping the population in the middle. The USA wants sanctions to continue I guess because they once had that wish dream to conquer Russia. The rationale behind the sanctions is to slowly strangle the Russian economy. No politician in Europe dares to speak in favor of Putin and against the American empire. 
Pity, because I'd like Russia to join the European Union because I think Russia is historically part of European culture and we didn't treat them fairly after they one-sidedly ended the cold war, dismantled the USSR and tried to embrace market economy. To nag on about Crimea is so childish, the people there voted to be part of Russia and they had the right.
The bulk of sanctions will stay the same. Some details may change but are unimportant. 
Also there's the possibility of a sudden crisis stirred up by the government in Ukraine that will put pressure on Europe to make sanctions heavier.
They will be relaxed in the long-term, but not before the situation in Ukraine shows marked improvement.

Haha correlates with #BREXIT, UK says they are the only EU country that stands up to Putin, and EU will fold if they leave. http://uatoday.tv/opinion/the-guardian-no-russia-sanctions-without-u-k-in-e-u-british-defence-ministry-660383.html
Face saving will require the bulk of sanctions to remain, however it will be seen as better to forget some and add a few others. There has been years to prepare for this.

US is maintaining sanctions as is, and EU will align with US on this, especially now that US has explicitly asked EU to do so ("US hopes EU will maintain" = "better do it!"). Anyway, expectations are fairly in favour of status quo at least till year end. See the links below. http://www.sfchronicle.com/news/politics/article/US-to-maintain-Russia-sanctions-hopes-EU-will-7940105.php http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN0YA134

Relations with Russia: EU's guiding principles
http://eeas.europa.eu/delegations/russia/press_corner/all_news/news/2016/20160315_en.htm "This, as I said, was not a difficult discussion. We had a very much united discussion and I believe this is going to be extremely relevant for the follow-up of our work. "
There seems to be no movement on either side which would justify not continuing the sanctions.

Not much time, but I'm going more for "half a loaf." Would undercut a bit of the "meddling EU" optics and I've got confidence there can be a creative way to craft it. Couldn't hurt to try to dial back the problems with Russia (wouldn't hurt Putin in the fall elections, not that I'd ever think there was any back room deal). We've seen in the other two (?) Russian sanctions questions that small moves are just enough for a "yes."

Based on recent chatter, there seems almost no reason to expect they'll be allowed to expire.  Getting agreement on how to modify them would be time-consuming and contentious.  Therefore the best bet as far as I can tell at the moment is to extend them as is with a new sunset date.
